data.name: BatchEditing_Text0
data.value:
The MultiRow control has built-in support for Excel-like, fast, in-cell editing.
Users can begin editing by simply typing into any cell (quick-edit mode), or by pressing F2 or clicking a cell twice (full-edit mode).
There is no need to add extra columns with 'Edit' buttons that switch between display and edit modes.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text1
data.value: There are two modes for updating data to server.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text2
data.value: In this mode, which is the default mode, the item updated or created gets committed to the server once the corresponding row finishes editing.</br>The removed row will be committed to the server immediately.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text3
data.value: If user wants to update the data, the Update action Url should be provided. If one wants to add or remove the data, the Create or the Delete action Url should be provided.</br>And the user should edit the data in the corresponding action.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text4
data.value: In this mode user can update, create or remove multiple items and commit all the changes to the data source once.</br>The user can commit multiple modifications by sorting, paging or filtering the grid data or simply on a button-click.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text5
data.value: The BatchEditing action Url should be provided in this mode.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text6
data.value:
Note: To disable data update during sort/filter/page operations, set the DisableServerRead property of MultiRow's ItemSource to True.
This will enable client-side sorting, filtering, paging and data will only be submitted when the collectionView's commit method is explicitly called from the client-side.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text7
data.value: Normal Mode

data.name: BatchEditing_Text8
data.value: Batch Mode

data.name: CollapsedHeaders_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how to collapse the column headers of MultiRow control to a single line, which shows only the group names rather than individual cells.

data.name: CollapsedHeaders_Text1
data.value: By default, the MultiRow control creates column headers that span multiple rows and shows the header for each cell defined in the LayoutDefinition.

data.name: CollapsedHeaders_Text2
data.value: These cell-specific column headers may be used to sort or filter the data as you would do in a conventional grid.

data.name: CollapsedHeaders_Text3
data.value:
In some cases, you may want to collapse the column headers to a single line, showing only the group names rather than individual cells.
This saves space at the expense of having individual cell headers. To collapse the column headers, set the CollapsedHeaders property to true.
In these scenarios, remember to set the Header property on the groups in order to avoid empty column headers.

data.name: CollapsedHeaders_Text4
data.value:
Setting the CollapsedHeaders property to null causes the grid to show all header information (groups and columns).
In this case, the first row will show the group headers and the remaining rows will show the individual column headers.

data.name: CustomCells_Text0
data.value: This sample demonstrates how to use custom cells feature of the MultiRow control.

data.name: CustomCells_Text1
data.value: The sample uses the TemplateId property to specify the id of the template for the "Trends" column.

data.name: CustomCells_Text2
data.value:
The sample also uses the ItemFormatter property to customize displaying "Rank" column.
In the ItemFormatter event handler, use the getBindingColumn function of MultiRow to get the binding column.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how you can customize the way to add rows or change the values in the cells of MultiRow control.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text1
data.value:
The sample uses the EditTemplateId property to specify the id of the template for cell editor.
When the user starts editing a cell, the editor will show and get the focus.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text2
data.value: There are three kinds of editors.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text3
data.value: You need to set the EditTemplate property of a cell.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text4
data.value:
If the grid allows adding a new row, you need to set the editor's IsRequired property to false.
If you want the editor with the whole cell, you can set the style width to "100%".

data.name: CustomEditors_Text5
data.value: In this sample, "Date", "Time", "Country", "Amount" and "Color" use C1 Input controls as the editors.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text6
data.value:
You need to use grid's OnClientCellEditEnding event and set

cellEditEndingEventArgs.cancel = true;

to apply your updates.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text7
data.value: Then you need to consider when to update the cell value and remove the editor from a grid in your application.</br>For example, when the editor blurs, we need to update the cell value and remove the editor.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text8
data.value: In this sample, the "Product" column uses <input /> as the editor.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text9
data.value: To get the binding column in the event handler, please use the MultiRow's getBindingColumn function.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text10
data.value: In this sample, "Amount2" and "Active" use grid's internal editor. Here, you do not need to do anything.

data.name: CustomEditors_Text11
data.value: Using C1 Input controls which have "Value" or "Text" property

data.name: CustomEditors_Text12
data.value: Using other control or a C1 control which has NO "Value" or "Text" property

data.name: CustomEditors_Text13
data.value: Using grid's internal editor

data.name: DataMap_Text0
data.value:
Data maps provide a grid with automatic look-up capabilities. For example, you may want to display a customer's name instead of his/her ID, or a color name instead of its RGB value.

Columns with an associated data map can be sorted by the mapped display value instead of the binding value.

Columns with an associated data map, in this sample, show drop-down buttons that can be used for quick editing. If you do not want to show the drop-down buttons, set the column's ShowDropDown property to false.

data.name: DataMap_Text1
data.value: Multi-column Data Map

data.name: DataMap_Text2
data.value: The columns of MultiRow control have a DropDownCssClass property that enables styling the drop-downs, used to edit values in data-mapped columns.

data.name: DataMap_Text3
data.value: To see the multi-column editor in action, click one of the drop-down buttons in the "Color" column,</br>or select a cell in that column and press F4:

data.name: DisableServerRead_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how to disable server-side reading in MultiRow control.

data.name: DisableServerRead_Text1
data.value:
This sample shows what the DisableServerRead property works for. When it is set to True, all the items will be transferred to the client side and the operations like sorting, paging, and filtering will be done on the client side.
Hence, "Loading..." text is not shown while loading the data when the scrollbar scrolls.
Otherwise, sorting, paging or filtering will be done at the server side, and sometimes "Loading..." text will be shown.

data.name: DisableServerRead_Text2
data.value: MultiRow without paging

data.name: DisableServerRead_Text3
data.value: Paging MultiRow which PageSize is set to 10

data.name: Editing_Text0
data.value:
The MultiRow control has built-in support for Excel-like, fast, in-cell editing.
There is no need to add extra columns with 'Edit' buttons that switch between display and edit modes.

data.name: Editing_Text1
data.value: Users can start editing simply by typing into any cell. This puts the cell in 'quick-edit' mode.</br>In this mode, pressing the cursor keys completes the editing and the grid moves the selection.

data.name: Editing_Text2
data.value: Another way to begin in-cell editing is by pressing F2 or by clicking a cell twice.</br>This puts the cell in 'full-edit' mode. In this mode, the cursor keys move the caret within the cell text and the user must press the Enter, Tab, or Escape keys to complete editing.

data.name: Editing_Text3
data.value:
Disable Editing
You can disable editing at grid or column levels using the IsReadOnly
property of grid or column objects.

data.name: Editing_Text4
data.value:
Mobile Devices:
Mobile devices use the double-click event to zoom in and out, and do not show
keyboard by default. To start editing a cell on mobile devices, users need to simply click
a cell to select it, then click it again to indicate they want to start editing.

data.name: Editing_Text5
data.value:
Automatic Type Validation/Coercion:
If the user types anything that is invalid for a column (e.g. "hello" for a
numeric or date column), the edits won't be applied and the cell will keep its
original value. Dates and times are parsed using the format assigned to the
column.

data.name: Editing_Text6
data.value:
Checkbox:
By default (and unlike Microsoft Excel), Boolean values are shown as checkboxes. Users
can change the checkbox values by clicking or by pressing the space bar.
Checkboxes are easier to read and to edit than fields containing "TRUE" or
"FALSE" strings.

data.name: Editing_Text7
data.value:
Update Modes:
The edited data gets updated to the datasource server, by default, once editing is done.
This is the normal update mode, for which users need to provide the Update, the Delete or the Create action url.
And the corresponding codes used to update the datasource should be written in the corresponding action.
However, users can also update, create or remove multiple items and commit them to the data source only once.
This is the batch update mode, for which users need to provide the BatchEditing action Url.

data.name: Editing_Text8
data.value: <input type="button" value="Read More" class="btn collapse in" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".collapsed-content, .btn.collapse" />

data.name: Editing_Text9
data.value: Here is a typical editable MultiRow:

data.name: Editing_Text10
data.value: Popup editing keeps the native editing enabled for quick Microsoft Excel-like data entry, and adds an "Edit Detail" button to invoke a form where the user can edit the item details.

data.name: Editing_Text11
data.value: To see this in action, select an item on the grid and click the "Edit Detail" button above.</br>This will bring up a form where users can edit the data for the currently selected item.

data.name: Editing_Text12
data.value: The detail form uses specialized input controls that take up more space but can make data entry easier in some cases. The form has "OK" and "Cancel" buttons that commit the changes or restore the original data. Both actions are accomplished with a single call to the CollectionView used as a data source for the grid.

data.name: Editing_Text13
data.value:
If for some reason you do not need the Microsoft Excel-style editing and prefer to add editing buttons to every row (typical of editable HTML tables), you can accomplish that by using ItemFormatter and a few controller methods.
To get the binding column in the ItemFormatter event handler, please use the MultiRow's getBindingColumn function.

data.name: Editing_Text14
data.value: The grid below demonstrates this approach. The buttons in the cells call the methods in the controller to perform the required actions:

data.name: ExcelExport_Text0
data.value: The sample demonstrates how to export the contents of MultiRow control to an Excel (xlsx) format.

data.name: ExcelExport_Text1
data.value:
To export MultiRow contents, pass the MultiRow instance to the FlexGridXlsxConverter.save method.
This generates xlsx file content, which can be saved to a local file or sent to a server.

data.name: ExcelExport_Text2
data.value: Note: You must add a jszip.js library to your application. Its CDN link is: http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jszip/2.2.1/jszip.min.js

data.name: Freezing_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how to use frozen cells feature in the MultiRow control.

data.name: Freezing_Text1
data.value:
The MultiRow control allows you to freeze rows and columns so they remain in view as the user scrolls the grid.
Frozen cells can be edited and selected as regular cells, same as in Microsoft Excel and in the FlexGrid control.

data.name: Grouping_Text0
data.value:
This sample shows how to use grouping support in the MultiRow control. Most of the work is done by the CollectionView class, which is used as a data source for the grid.
You can configure group description by GroupBy method in view.
To add grouping by Javascript, add one or more GroupDescription objects to the CollectionView.GroupDescriptions property.
And ensure that the MultiRow's ShowGroups property is set to true.

data.name: Grouping_Text1
data.value:
You can customize the text that is displayed in group header rows using the MultiRow's GroupHeaderFormat property.
By default, this displays the name of the group, for example, State, followed by the current group and the number of items in the group.

data.name: Index_Text0
data.value: Traditional grid view, with one row per record.The user must scroll horizontally to see the whole record.

data.name: Index_Text1
data.value: This view uses two rows per record. The layout is divided into three groups: order, customer, and shipper.

data.name: Index_Text2
data.value: This view uses three rows per record. The layout is divided into three groups: order, customer, and shipper.

data.name: Index_Text3
data.value: The MultiRow control extends conventional grid layouts by using multiple rows to represent each data item.

data.name: Index_Text4
data.value: The MultiRow control extends conventional grid layouts by using multiple rows to represent each data item.

data.name: Index_Text5
data.value:
The MultiRow control allows users to see and edit data in a tabular format, just like other conventional grids.
However, MultiRow is different from these grids in a way that it allows you to bind each data item to multiple rows,
creating form-like interfaces that can display a large number of columns with minimal horizontal scrolling.

data.name: Index_Text6
data.value:
The MultiRow control extends the FlexGrid control, so if you know how to use FlexGrid, you will be able to use MultiRow in no time.
The main new property is LayoutDefinition, which takes an object that describes the layout of the grid rows and cells.

data.name: Index_Text7
data.value: The MultiRow control is not a simple replacement for conventional grids; it is a specialized tool that fits some particular scenarios really well.

data.name: Index_Text8
data.value:
The LayoutDefinition property specifies the layout of cells in a grid.
It contains a list of cell group objects. Each cell group specifies how many columns the group should span, and the cells that make up each group.

data.name: Index_Text9
data.value: The image below illustrates how a cell group is interpreted and turned into a grid layout:</br>

data.name: Index_Text10
data.value:
Here, the group spans three grid columns. It contains six cells with different spans.
When generating the layout, the grid fits as many cells as possible in each row, and wraps to the next row when the group span is reached.
The last cell in each row is automatically expanded to fill Colspan of the group.
The process is similar to wrapping of text to create a paragraph.

data.name: Index_Text11
data.value: The same process is applied to every group in the LayoutDefinition object.

data.name: Paging_Text0
data.value:
This sample shows how to implement paged views with the MultiRow control.
All the work is done by the CollectionView class, which is used as a data source for the grid.
To enable paging, set the PageSize property of MultiRow or CollectionViewService.
To switch pages, use the Pager control and set Pager.Owner property to the id of MultiRow or CollectionViewService.

data.name: Paging_Text1
data.value: In this example, paging happens on server-side. This is because CollectionView here acts like a service and synchronizes with server data. The CollectionView internally does an ajax call to fetch next set of data. Refer @Html.ActionLink("Disable Server Reading", "DisableServerRead") sample for client-side paging.

data.name: Paging_Text2
data.value:
Note: The paging UI is implemented outside the grid. This gives you complete control over the appearance and functionality of the paging mechanism.
To customize the Pager control by Javascript, refer the client CollectionView class.

data.name: PdfExport_Text0
data.value:
You can use the FlexGridPdfConverter, a PDFKit-based JavaScript library,
to export the contents of MultiRow control to PDF (Portable Document Format) without using any server-side code.

data.name: PdfExport_Text1
data.value: To export the contents of MultiRow control, you need to use the FlexGridPdfConverter.export function that takes the following arguments:

data.name: PdfExport_Text2
data.value: In this sample, you can change the following export settings by using the menus below:

data.name: PdfExport_Text3
data.value:
In this sample, MultiRow uses font Fira and two typefaces, FiraSans-Regular.ttf and FiraSans-Bold.ttf.
The FiraSans-Bold.ttf (boldface) typeface is used to display the header cells, and the FiraSans-Regular.ttf typeface is used for the rest of the content.

data.name: PdfExport_Text4
data.value: To embed the fonts in the PDF, the following export settings are used:

data.name: PdfExport_Text5
data.value: A MultiRow instance

data.name: PdfExport_Text6
data.value: Name of the file to export

data.name: PdfExport_Text7
data.value: Export settings

data.name: PdfExport_Text8
data.value: scaleMode: Determines how the MultiRow contents should be scaled in order to fit the page.

data.name: PdfExport_Text9
data.value: orientation: Determines the orientation of pages.

data.name: PdfExport_Text10
data.value: exportMode: Determines which part of the MultiRow control should be exported (all the data or only the current selection).

data.name: PdfExport_Text11
data.value: embeddedFonts: Provides information to the export library about various custom fonts to be embedded, such as URL, name, style, weight.

data.name: PdfExport_Text12
data.value: styles: It is used to set up the style for the grid elements and link them with the embedded fonts.

data.name: PdfExport_Text13
data.value: Export Settings:

data.name: Styling_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how you can use built-in class names in CSS rules to customize the appearance of the record and group delimiters.

data.name: Styling_Text1
data.value:
In most of the applications, you would want to show where each record and group starts or ends.
The MultiRow control enables this by adding CSS class names to cell elements in the first and last row/column of each group.
The class names are wj-record-start, wj-record-end, wj-group-start, and wj-group-end.

data.name: Styling_Text2
data.value:
This example shows how you can use these class names in CSS rules to customize the appearance of the record and group delimiters.
It also shows how you can use the standard CssClass property to customize the appearance of specific cells within groups.

data.name: UnobtrusiveValidation_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how to use unobtrusive validation in the MultiRow control.

data.name: UnobtrusiveValidation_Text1
data.value:
The columns have the following validations:

  • Name: Required. Alphanumeric and contains 4 to 10 characters.

  • Industry: Required.

  • Country: Required.

  • Phone: Required. 8 to 11 characters.

  • Email: Required. Valid e-mail address.

  • Birthdate: Required.

data.name: VirtualScrolling_Text0
data.value: This sample shows how to make the MultiRow control work in virtual scrolling mode.

data.name: VirtualScrolling_Text1
data.value:
To enable this functionality, the DisableServerRead property should be set to false (default).
Then the InitialItemsCount property should be set to a number that is greater than 0.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text9
data.value: This sample shows the Batch update mode for updating the MultiRow data to server.

data.name: DataMap_Text4
data.value: This sample demonstrates how to use data map feature, which provides the MultiRow control with automatic look-up capabilities.

data.value: New row at top:

data.name: CustomEditors_Text15
data.value: This sample uses the property NewRowAtTop displaying as checkbox to enable adding new row at the top or bottom of the grid.

data.name: Grouping_Text2
data.value: The MultiRowGroupHeaders property determines whether group headers should have multiple rows instead of a single header row, which is useful when you want to display aggregate values in the group headers.

data.name: CustomColumnHeader_Text0
data.value: The HeaderLayoutDefinition property defines the layout of the rows used to display the grid's column headers. The array contains a list of cell group objects similar to those used with the LayoutDefinition property.

data.name: RowHeader_Description_Text0
data.value: The layout is divided into three groups: customer, order, and shipper. Customer is a row header group. Setting the IsRowHeader property to true automatically sets the cell's IsReadOnly property to true (headers cannot be edited), adds a 'wj-header' style to the cell's CssClass property (so the cells are styled as headers), and sets the cell's CellTemplate property to its Header value (so the cell shows the header as an unbound string). You may choose to set the cell's Binding property instead of Header if you want to show bound values in the row header cells.

data.name: RowHeader_Summary_Text0
data.value: The IsRowHeader property of the cell groups allows you to create groups to be displayed as row header cells.

data.name: BatchEditing_Text10
data.value: Update

data.name: Grouping_Text3
data.value: Collapse All

data.name: Grouping_Text4
data.value: Expand All

data.value: Drag columns here to create Groups

data.value: Drag columns here...
